<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=43,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=750759,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DQ1033A.;39',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:08' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1033_1_42"> </A>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Unit Case Volume  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although most of our Company's revenues are not based directly on unit case volume, we believe unit case volume is one of the measures of the underlying strength
of the Coca-Cola system because it measures trends at the consumer level. The Coca-Cola system sold approximately 20.6&nbsp;billion unit cases of our products in 2005,
approximately 19.8&nbsp;billion unit cases in 2004, and approximately 19.4&nbsp;billion unit cases in 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the North America operating segment, unit case volume in the Retail Division increased 2&nbsp;percent in 2005 versus 2004, reflecting improved performance in the bottle-delivered
business primarily related to Dasani, Coca-Cola Zero and noncarbonated beverages, along with growth in the warehouse juice and warehouse water operations. The Foodservice and Hospitality Division had
a 1&nbsp;percent increase in 2005 compared to 2004, reflecting improved trends in restaurant traffic and the impact of new customer conversion partially offset by the impact of higher fuel costs and
Hurricane Katrina on consumer restaurant spending. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the Africa operating segment, unit case volume increased 6&nbsp;percent in 2005 compared to 2004. This increase was driven by growth in core carbonated soft drinks as well as
noncarbonated beverages across all divisions in this operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the East, South Asia and Pacific Rim operating segment, unit case volume decreased 4&nbsp;percent in 2005 compared to 2004, primarily due to declines in India and the Philippines.
The decline in India was related to the impact of price increases to cover rising raw material and distribution costs and the lingering effects of the 2003 pesticide allegations. The decline in the
Philippines was primarily related to affordability and availability issues. Both markets are expected to remain challenging in 2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unit
case volume in the European Union operating segment was even in 2005 versus 2004, primarily due to strong growth in Spain and Central Europe partially offset by declines primarily
in Germany and Northwest Europe. Unit case volume in Germany declined 2&nbsp;percent in 2005 due to the continued impact of the mandatory deposit legislation on the availability of nonrefillable
packages and the corresponding limited availability of our products in the discount retail channel, along with overall industry weakness. In the second half of 2005, the Company achieved a limited
range of availability of its products in most discounters. Results in Germany stabilized in the second half of 2005, and we expect this to continue into 2006. Unit case volume in Northwest Europe
declined 3&nbsp;percent in 2005, primarily due to the soft economic environment and declines in the carbonated soft drink category, which is associated with a decrease in prices at retailers, and
the discount channel becoming a larger part of the retail market, together with a shift in consumer preferences away from regular carbonated soft drinks driven by health and wellness trends and the
associated public opinion, media and government attention. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unit
case volume for the Latin America operating segment increased 6&nbsp;percent in 2005 versus 2004, reflecting strong growth in Brazil, Argentina and Mexico, primarily due to growth
in carbonated soft drinks. The increase in Brazil and Mexico was primarily due to strong marketing, execution and package innovation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the North Asia, Eurasia and Middle East operating segment, unit case volume grew 15&nbsp;percent in 2005 versus 2004, led by 22&nbsp;percent growth in China, 2&nbsp;percent
growth in Japan, 54&nbsp;percent growth in Russia and 14&nbsp;percent growth in Turkey. The increase in unit case volume in China was led by significant growth in both carbonated soft drinks and
noncarbonated beverages. Japan's growth was primarily due to new product introductions. The unit case volume growth in Turkey was largely due to improving macroeconomic trends, strong bottler
execution and successful marketing programs. The unit case volume growth in Russia was the result of the joint acquisition of Multon as well as improving macroeconomic trends, strong bottler execution
and successful marketing programs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the North America operating segment, unit case volume for 2004 was even compared to 2003. The Retail Division had a 1&nbsp;percent decrease in unit case volume in 2004 versus 2003,
primarily due to poor weather in the third quarter, higher retail pricing and lower than expected results from Coca-Cola C2. The Foodservice and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=44,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=663673,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DQ1033A.;39',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:08' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1033_1_43"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Hospitality
Division's unit case volume increased 2&nbsp;percent as a result of effective customer programs and improved restaurant traffic. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the Africa operating segment, unit case volume increased 3&nbsp;percent in 2004 compared to 2003, primarily as a result of the growth in South Africa, where unit case volume
increased 7&nbsp;percent, and in Morocco and Kenya. These increases were partially offset by unit case volume declines in Nigeria, due to de-emphasis on less-profitable water
packages and weakness in noncore brands, and in Egypt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the East, South Asia and Pacific Rim operating segment, unit case volume increased 1&nbsp;percent in 2004 versus 2003, primarily as a result of the growth in the South East and West
Asia Division, partially offset by an 8&nbsp;percent decline in the Philippines due to affordability and availability issues. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unit
case volume in the European Union operating segment decreased 3&nbsp;percent in 2004 versus 2003, primarily due to limited brand and package availability in the discount retail
channel in Germany resulting from the mandatory deposit legislation and poor weather conditions in northern Europe. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unit
case volume for the Latin America operating segment increased 3&nbsp;percent in 2004 versus 2003, primarily reflecting strong growth in Brazil, Argentina and Venezuela resulting
from the execution of the Company's long-term investment strategy with an emphasis on brand building, new package alternatives, and close coordination with bottling partners to drive
superior local marketplace execution, offset by a de-emphasis on large-format water and powdered drinks in Mexico. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
North Asia, Eurasia and Middle East operating segment's unit case volume increased 12&nbsp;percent in 2004 compared to 2003, primarily led by 22&nbsp;percent growth in China as a
result of a new advertising campaign, innovative packaging and promotion in the cities, and affordable 200ml packaging in the towns. Japan's growth of 4&nbsp;percent was driven by Trademark
Coca-Cola unit case volume growth of 3&nbsp;percent and Trademark Fanta growth of 17&nbsp;percent. Unit case volume growth in Turkey, Russia and the Middle East was mainly due to
successful promotions and continued positive economic trends. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Gallon Sales  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2005, the 1&nbsp;percent increase in gallon sales in the North America operating segment was primarily related to the Retail Division. In Africa, the
7&nbsp;percent gallon sales growth was led by South Africa, Nigeria and Egypt. In Latin America, the 6&nbsp;percent gallon sales increase was led by growth in Brazil, Mexico and Argentina. The
12&nbsp;percent increase in gallon sales in the North Asia, Eurasia and Middle East operating segment was primarily due to growth in China, Russia and Turkey. Japan gallon sales were slightly higher
in 2005 compared to 2004. The increases in gallon sales in the North America; the Africa; the Latin America; and the North Asia, Eurasia and Middle East operating segments were offset by a
1&nbsp;percent decrease in the European Union operating segment and a 6&nbsp;percent decrease in the East, South Asia and Pacific Rim operating segment. In the European Union operating segment,
gallon sales decreased 1&nbsp;percent, with the largest declines occurring in Germany and Northwest Europe, partially offset by growth in Spain and Central Europe. In the East, South Asia and
Pacific Rim operating segment, gallon sales decreased 6&nbsp;percent, primarily due to the continuing challenging conditions in India and the Philippines. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
decrease in gallon sales in Germany was primarily due to the continuing impact of the mandatory deposit legislation on nonrefillable beverage packages and the corresponding limited
availability of our products in the discount retail channel, along with overall industry weakness. In the second half of 2005, the Company achieved a limited range of availability of its products in
most discounters. Results in Germany stabilized in the second half of 2005. The German legislature passed an amendment to the mandatory deposit legislation that will require retailers, including
discounters, to accept returns of each type of nonrefillable beverage containers they sell, regardless of where the beverage package type was purchased, the amendment allows for a transition period
until mid-2006. We expect the German business to continue to stabilize during 2006. For a discussion of the operating environment in Germany, refer to the heading "Critical Accounting
Policies and Estimates&#151; </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=45,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=343768,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DQ1033A.;39',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:08' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1033_1_44"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Goodwill,
Trademarks and Other Intangible Assets." We will continue to focus on improving our short-term performance and strengthening our system's long-term capabilities in
Germany. The decrease in gallon sales in Northwest Europe was primarily due to the soft economic environment and declines in the carbonated soft drink category, which is associated with a decrease in
prices at retailers, and the discount channel becoming a larger part of the retail market, together with a shift in consumer preferences away from regular carbonated soft drinks driven by health and
wellness trends and the associated public opinion, media and government attention. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
decrease in gallon sales in India was primarily due to the impact of price increases to cover rising raw material and distribution costs and the lingering effects of the 2003
pesticide allegations. The decline in gallon sales in the Philippines was primarily due to continued affordability and availability issues. The Company is continuing to focus on improving our
performance in these markets; however, India and the Philippines will remain difficult during 2006. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Company-wide
gallon sales grew 3&nbsp;percent while unit case volume grew 4&nbsp;percent in 2005 compared to 2004. In the North America operating segment, gallon sales increased
1&nbsp;percent while unit case volume increased 2&nbsp;percent in 2005 compared to 2004, primarily due to the impact of higher gallon sales in 2004 related to the launch of Coca-Cola
C2 and a change in shipping routes in 2004. In the Africa operating segment, gallon sales growth of 7&nbsp;percent exceeded unit case volume growth of 6&nbsp;percent, primarily due to timing of
gallon shipments. In the European Union operating segment, gallon sales declined by 1&nbsp;percent while unit case volume was even in 2005, mostly due to the timing of 2004 gallon sales throughout
most of the operating segment and planned inventory reductions primarily in Spain, Greece and Israel. In the East, South Asia and Pacific Rim operating segment, gallon sales declines were ahead of
unit case volume declines primarily due to timing of gallon sales in India and the Philippines and planned inventory reductions in Australia. In the North Asia, Eurasia and Middle East operating
segment, unit case volume increased ahead of gallon sales volume due to the joint acquisition of Multon, which contributed to unit case volume in 2005, along with timing of 2004 gallon sales impacting
most of the remaining divisions in the operating segment. Multon had full year unit case volume of approximately 80&nbsp;million unit cases in 2004. The Company reports only unit case volume related
to Multon, as the Company does not sell concentrate to Multon. In the Latin America operating segment, gallon sales growth and unit case volume growth were approximately equal in 2005 compared to
2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
2&nbsp;percent increase in gallon sales in the North America operating segment in 2004 compared to 2003 was primarily related to 4&nbsp;percent growth in the Foodservice and
Hospitality Division and 1&nbsp;percent growth in the Retail Division. The 4&nbsp;percent growth in the Africa operating segment was led mainly by South Africa. The 3&nbsp;percent increase in
the Latin America operating segment was primarily driven by growth in Brazil, Mexico and Argentina. The North Asia, Eurasia and Middle East operating segment's growth of 12&nbsp;percent was driven
by gallon sales growth in China, Turkey and Russia. The 3&nbsp;percent decrease in gallon sales in the European Union resulted primarily from the decline in Germany primarily due to market shifts
related to the deposit law on nonrefillable beverage packages and the corresponding lack of availability of our products in the discount retail channel. The East, South Asia and Pacific Rim operating
segment's gallon sales decreased 2&nbsp;percent in 2004 compared to 2003 primarily due to inventory reductions in India and challenging conditions in the Philippines. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Company-wide
gallon sales growth of 2&nbsp;percent was in line with unit case volume growth in 2004 compared to 2003. However, in the North America operating segment, gallon sales
increased 2&nbsp;percent while unit case volume was even due to lower gallon sales in 2003, additional 2004 shipments related to new product introductions, changes in our shipping routes and higher
than expected year end sales. In the East, South Asia and Pacific Rim operating segment, gallon sales declined 2&nbsp;percent while unit case sales increased 1&nbsp;percent primarily due to timing
of gallon sales. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<TD COLSPAN=2><FONT SIZE=2>Interest expense</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>240</B></FONT></TD>

<TD WIDTH="9%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>196</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>178</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>22</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>10</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TD COLSPAN=2><FONT SIZE=2>Equity income &#151; net</FONT></TD>

<A NAME="page_ds1033_1_46"> </A>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Net Operating Revenues  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net operating revenues increased by $1,362&nbsp;million or 6&nbsp;percent in 2005 versus 2004. Net operating revenues increased by $885&nbsp;million or
4&nbsp;percent in 2004 versus 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table indicates, on a percentage basis, the estimated impact of key factors resulting in significant increases (decreases) in net operating revenues: </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Refer to the heading "Volume" for a detailed discussion on gallon sales. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Structural
changes refers to acquisitions or dispositions of bottling or canning operations and consolidation or deconsolidation of entities for accounting purposes. During the third
quarter of 2005, our Company acquired the German soft drink bottling company Bremer Erfrischungsgetraenke GmbH ("Bremer"). Refer to Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
Structural changes also reflect the impact of a full year of revenue in 2005 for variable interest entities compared to a partial year in 2004. Under Interpretation&nbsp;46(R), the results of
operations of variable interest entities in which the Company was determined to be the primary beneficiary were included in our consolidated results beginning April&nbsp;2, 2004. Refer to
Note&nbsp;1 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
favorable impact of foreign currency fluctuations in 2005 versus 2004 resulted from the strength of most key foreign currencies versus the U.S. dollar, especially a stronger euro
that favorably impacted the European Union operating segment, and a stronger Brazilian real and Mexican peso that favorably impacted our Latin America operating segment. The favorable impact of
fluctuation in these currencies was offset by a weaker Japanese yen that unfavorably impacted the North Asia, Eurasia and Middle East operating segment. Refer to the heading "Liquidity, Capital
Resources and Financial Position&#151;Foreign Exchange." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Structural
changes resulted in a decrease in net operating revenues in 2004 compared to 2003, primarily due to the creation of a national supply chain company in Japan in 2003. Effective
October&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company and all of our bottling partners in Japan created a nationally integrated supply chain management company to centralize procurement, production and logistics
operations for the entire Coca-Cola system in Japan. As a result, a portion of our Company's business was essentially converted from a finished product business model to a concentrate
business model. This shift of certain products to a concentrate business model resulted in reductions in our revenues and cost of goods sold, each in the same amount. This change in the business model
did not impact gross profit. The decrease in net revenues from 2003 to 2004 attributable to the Japan structural change was approximately $780&nbsp;million, which was partially offset by an
approximately $260&nbsp;million increase in revenues associated with the consolidation as of April&nbsp;2, 2004 of certain bottling operations that are considered variable interest entities under
Interpretation 46(R). Refer to Note&nbsp;1 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
impact of foreign currency fluctuations versus the U.S. dollar in 2004 versus 2003 was driven primarily by the stronger euro, which favorably impacted the European Union operating
segment, and the stronger Japanese yen, which favorably impacted the North Asia, Eurasia and Middle East operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="70%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>100.0</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE=2><B>%</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>100.0</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE=2>%</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>100.0</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>%</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=7><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The percentage contribution of each operating segment has changed due to net operating revenues in certain segments growing at a faster rate
compared to the other operating segments and the impact of foreign currency fluctuations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
January&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company granted our bottling partners in Spain the rights to manufacture and distribute Company trademarked products in can packages. Prior to
granting these rights to our bottling partners, the Company held the manufacturing and distribution rights for these can packages in Spain. As a result of granting these rights, the Company will
reduce our planned future annual marketing support payments made to our bottling partners in Spain. As a result, a portion of our Company's business has
essentially been converted from a finished product business model to a concentrate business model. This shift to a concentrate business model will result in an annual reduction to net revenues. The
Company estimates the decrease in annual net revenues from this structural change to be approximately $775&nbsp;million. We do not believe this change in business model will have a significant
impact on gross profit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
size and timing of structural changes, including acquisitions or dispositions of bottling and canning operations, do not occur consistently from period to period. As a result,
anticipating the impact of such events on future increases or decreases in net operating revenues (and other financial statement line items) usually is not possible. However, we expect to continue to
sell bottling and canning interests and buy bottling and canning interests in limited circumstances and, as a result, structural changes will continue to affect our consolidated financial statements
in future periods. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Gross Profit  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our gross profit margin decreased to 64.5&nbsp;percent in 2005 from 64.7&nbsp;percent in 2004, primarily due to higher raw material and freight costs driven
by rising oil prices. This decrease was partially offset by the receipt of settlement proceeds of approximately $109&nbsp;million related to a class action lawsuit settlement concerning price-fixing
in the sale of high fructose corn syrup purchased by the Company during the years 1991 to 1995. Subsequent to the receipt of this settlement, the Company distributed approximately $62&nbsp;million
to certain bottlers in North America. From 1991 to 1995, the Company purchased high fructose corn syrup on behalf of these bottlers; therefore, these bottlers were ultimately entitled to the proceeds
of the settlement. The Company's portion of the settlement was approximately $47&nbsp;million, which was recorded as a reduction of cost of goods sold and impacted the Corporate operating segment.
Refer to Note&nbsp;17 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. Our gross margin was also impacted by the consolidation of certain bottling operations under Interpretation 46(R) as of
April&nbsp;2, 2004. Refer to Note&nbsp;1 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. Generally, bottling and finished product operations produce higher net revenues but lower gross profit
margins compared to concentrate and syrup operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
profit margin was approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points higher in 2004 versus 2003. This increase was primarily the result of the creation of a nationally integrated supply
chain management company in Japan in October&nbsp;2003 (refer to the heading "Net Operating Revenues," above), partially offset by the consolidation as of </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=49,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=354843,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DS1033A.;56',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1033_1_48"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>April&nbsp;2,
2004, of variable interest entities under Interpretation 46(R). Generally, bottling and finished product operations, such as our Japan tea business, which was integrated into the
supply chain company, produce higher net revenues but lower gross profit margins compared to concentrate and syrup operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling, general and administrative expenses were approximately 11&nbsp;percent higher in 2005 versus 2004. Approximately 1&nbsp;percentage
point of this increase was due to an overall weaker U.S. dollar (especially compared to the Brazilian real, the Mexican peso and the euro). The increase in selling, advertising and general and
administrative expenses is primarily related to increased marketing and innovation expenses and the full-year impact of the consolidation of certain bottling operations under Interpretation 46(R). Our
Company intends to maintain the increased level in marketing and innovation spending for the foreseeable future. The decrease in stock-based compensation expense is primarily related to the lower
average fair value per share of stock options expensed in the current year compared to the average fair value per share expensed in 2004. This decrease was partially offset by approximately
$50&nbsp;million of accelerated amortization
of compensation expense related to a change in our estimated service period for retirement-eligible participants when the terms of their stock-based compensation awards provided for accelerated
vesting upon early retirement. Refer to Note 14 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling,
general and administrative expenses were approximately 8&nbsp;percent higher in 2004 versus 2003. Approximately 3&nbsp;percentage points of this increase was due to an
overall weaker U.S. dollar (especially compared to the euro and Japanese yen). Increased selling expenses were due to increased delivery costs related to our Company's finished products business and
structural changes. Increased advertising expenses were the result of investments in marketing activities, such as the launch of new products in North America and Japan. Additionally, general and
administrative expenses increased due to higher legal expenses, asset write-offs and structural changes. Finally, we received a $75&nbsp;million insurance settlement related to the class
action lawsuit that was settled in 2000. The Company subsequently donated $75&nbsp;million to The Coca-Cola Foundation. </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=50,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=694383,FOLIO='48',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DS1033A.;56',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1033_1_49"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other operating charges in 2005 reflected the impact of approximately $84&nbsp;million of expenses related to impairment charges for intangible
assets and approximately $1&nbsp;million related to an impairment of other assets. These intangible assets primarily relate to trademark beverages sold in the Philippines, which is part of the East,
South Asia and Pacific Rim operating segment. Refer to the heading "Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#151;Goodwill, Trademarks and Other Intangible Assets." </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
operating charges in 2004 reflected the impact of approximately $480&nbsp;million of expenses primarily related to impairment charges for franchise rights and certain
manufacturing assets. The European Union operating segment accounted for approximately $368&nbsp;million of the impairment charges, which were primarily related to the impairment of franchise rights
at CCEAG. For a discussion of the operating environment in Germany, refer to the heading "Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#151;Goodwill, Trademarks and Other Intangible Assets." The
Corporate operating segment accounted for approximately $64&nbsp;million of impairment charges, which were primarily related to the impairment of certain manufacturing assets. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
operating charges in 2003 included the impact of approximately $561&nbsp;million of expenses related to the 2003 streamlining initiatives. A majority of the charges related to
initiatives in North America and Germany. In North America, the Company integrated the operations of three separate North American business units&#151;Coca-Cola North America, The
Minute Maid Company and Coca-Cola Fountain. In Germany, CCEAG took steps to improve its efficiency in sales, distribution and manufacturing, and our German Division office also implemented
streamlining initiatives. Selected other locations also took steps to streamline their operations to improve overall efficiency and effectiveness. These initiatives resulted in the separation of
approximately 3,700 associates in 2003, primarily in North America and Germany, and certain countries in the East, South Asia and Pacific Rim operating segment. Refer to Note&nbsp;18 of Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Information about our operating margin by operating segment is as follows: </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>49</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=51,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=820361,FOLIO='49',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DS1033A.;56',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1033_1_50"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As demonstrated by the tables above, the percentage contribution to operating income and operating margin by each operating segment fluctuated
from year to year. Operating income and operating margin by operating segment were influenced by a variety of factors and events, primarily the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2005, operating income increased approximately 7&nbsp;percent. Of this amount, 4&nbsp;percent was due to favorable foreign currency exchange primarily related to the
Brazilian real and the Mexican peso, which impacted the Latin America operating segment, and the euro, which impacted the European Union operating segment.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2005, the increase in net operating revenues and gross profit was partially offset by increased spending on marketing and innovation activities in each operating segment.
Refer to the headings "Net Operating Revenues" and "Selling, General and Administrative Expenses."
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2005, as a result of impairment charges totaling approximately $85&nbsp;million related to the Philippines, operating margins in the East, South Asia and Pacific Rim
operating segment decreased. Refer to the heading "Other Operating Charges."
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2005, operating income in the Corporate operating segment decreased $146&nbsp;million, primarily due to increased marketing and innovation expenses, which were
partially offset by our receipt of a net settlement of approximately $47&nbsp;million related to a class action lawsuit concerning the purchase of high fructose corn syrup. Refer to the headings
"Gross Profit" and "Selling, General and Administrative Expenses."
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2004, operating income was reduced by approximately $18&nbsp;million for the North America operating segment; $15&nbsp;million for the East, South Asia and Pacific
Rim operating segment; $368&nbsp;million for the European Union operating segment; $6&nbsp;million for the Latin America operating segment; $9&nbsp;million for
the North Asia, Eurasia and Middle East operating segment and $64&nbsp;million for Corporate as a result of impairment charges. Refer to the heading "Other Operating Charges."
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2004, operating income increased approximately 9&nbsp;percent. Of this amount, 8&nbsp;percent was due to favorable foreign currency exchange primarily related to the
euro, which impacted the European Union operating segment, and the Japanese yen, which impacted the North Asia, Eurasia and Middle East operating segment.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2004, as a result of the creation of a nationally integrated supply chain management company in Japan, operating margins in the North Asia, Eurasia and Middle East
operating segment increased. Generally, finished product operations produce higher net revenues but lower operating margins compared to concentrate and syrup operations. Refer to the heading "Net
Operating Revenues."
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2004, operating income in the Corporate operating segment increased $75&nbsp;million due to the receipt of an insurance settlement related to the class action lawsuit
which was settled in 2000.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2004, operating income in the Corporate operating segment decreased $75&nbsp;million due to a donation to The Coca-Cola Foundation.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2004, as a result of the consolidation of certain bottling operations that are considered variable interest entities under Interpretation 46(R), operating margins for the
Africa; East, South Asia and Pacific Rim; European Union; and North Asia, Eurasia and Middle East operating segments were reduced. Generally, bottling operations produce higher net revenues but lower
operating margins compared to concentrate and syrup operations.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>As
a result of streamlining charges, 2003 operating income was reduced by approximately $273&nbsp;million for the North America operating segment, $12&nbsp;million for
the Africa operating segment, $11&nbsp;million for the East, South Asia and Pacific Rim operating segments, $157&nbsp;million for the European Union operating segment, $8&nbsp;million for the
Latin America operating segment, $33&nbsp;million for North Asia, Eurasia and </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>50</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=52,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=521878,FOLIO='50',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DS1033A.;56',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1033_1_51"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Middle
East operating segment and $67&nbsp;million for the Corporate operating segment. Refer to Note&nbsp;18 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2003, operating income of the European Union operating segment significantly increased due to innovation and strong marketing strategies, rigorous cost management,
positive currency trends and favorable weather during the summer months.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>As
a result of the Company's receipt of a settlement related to a vitamin antitrust litigation matter operating income in 2003 increased by approximately $52&nbsp;million
for Corporate. Refer to Note&nbsp;17 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Interest Income and Interest Expense  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We monitor our mix of fixed-rate and variable-rate debt as well as our mix of term debt versus non-term debt. From time to
time we enter into interest rate swap agreements to manage our mix of fixed-rate and variable-rate debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2005, interest income increased by $78&nbsp;million compared to 2004, primarily due to higher average short-term investment balances and higher average interest rates on
U.S. dollar denominated deposits. Interest expense in 2005 increased by $44&nbsp;million compared to 2004, primarily due to higher average interest rates on commercial paper borrowings in the United
States, partially offset by lower interest expense at CCEAG due to the repayment of current maturities of long-term debt in 2005. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2004, interest income decreased by $19&nbsp;million compared to 2003, primarily due to lower interest income earned on short-term investments and interest income in 2003
related to certain tax receivables. While our Company's average short-term investment balances increased during 2004, significant amounts of these balances were held in lower
interest-earning locations than in prior years
while the Company analyzed the impact of the Jobs Creation Act. Interest expense in 2004 increased by $18&nbsp;million compared to 2003, primarily as a result of higher average interest rates and
higher average balances on commercial paper borrowings in the United States. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Equity Income&#151;Net  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company's share of income from equity method investments for 2005 totaled $680&nbsp;million compared to $621&nbsp;million in 2004, an increase of
approximately $59&nbsp;million or 10&nbsp;percent, primarily due to the overall improving health of the Coca-Cola bottling system in most of the world and the joint acquisition of
Multon in April&nbsp;2005. The increase was offset by approximately $33&nbsp;million related to our proportionate share of certain charges recorded by CCE. These charges included approximately
$51&nbsp;million, primarily related to the tax liability resulting from the repatriation of previously unremitted foreign earnings under the Jobs Creation Act, and approximately $18&nbsp;million
due to restructuring charges recorded by CCE. These charges were offset by approximately $37&nbsp;million from CCE's high fructose corn syrup lawsuit settlement and changes in certain of CCE's state
and provincial tax rates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company's share of income from equity method investments for 2004 totaled $621&nbsp;million compared to $406&nbsp;million in 2003, an increase of $215&nbsp;million or
53&nbsp;percent. Equity income for 2004 benefited by approximately $37&nbsp;million from our proportionate share of a favorable tax settlement related to Coca-Cola FEMSA. Additionally,
our equity income for 2003 was negatively impacted by a $102&nbsp;million charge primarily related to Coca-Cola FEMSA, as described below. Comparing 2004 to 2003, our equity income also
benefited from favorable pricing at key bottling operations, the positive impact of the strength of most key currencies versus the U.S. dollar, especially a stronger euro, and the overall improving
health of the Coca-Cola bottling system in most of the world. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
May&nbsp;6, 2003, one of our Company's Latin American equity method investees, Coca-Cola FEMSA, consummated a merger with another of the Company's Latin American
equity method investees, Panamerican Beverages,&nbsp;Inc. ("Panamco"). Our Company received new Coca-Cola FEMSA shares in exchange for all the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>51</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=53,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=847043,FOLIO='51',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DS1033A.;56',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1033_1_52"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Panamco
shares previously held by the Company. Our Company's ownership interest in Coca-Cola FEMSA increased from 30&nbsp;percent to approximately 40&nbsp;percent as a result of this
merger. This exchange of shares was treated as a nonmonetary exchange of similar productive assets, and no gain was recorded by our Company as a result of this merger. In connection with the merger,
Coca-Cola FEMSA management initiated steps to streamline and integrate the operations. This process included the closing of various distribution centers and manufacturing plants.
Furthermore, due to the challenging economic conditions and an uncertain political situation in Venezuela, certain intangible assets were determined to be impaired and written down to their fair
market value. During 2003, our Company recorded a noncash charge of $102&nbsp;million primarily related to our proportionate share of these matters. This charge is included in the line item equity
income&#151;net. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Other Loss&#151;Net  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other loss&#151;net amounted to a net loss of $93&nbsp;million for 2005 compared to a net loss of $82&nbsp;million for 2004. This line item in 2005
primarily consisted of $23&nbsp;million in foreign currency exchange losses, the accretion of $60&nbsp;million for the discounted value of our liability to purchase CCEAG shares (refer to
Note&nbsp;7 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements) and the minority shareowners' proportional share of net income of certain consolidated subsidiaries. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
loss&#151;net amounted to a net loss of $82&nbsp;million for 2004 compared to a net loss of $138&nbsp;million for 2003, a difference of $56&nbsp;million. Approximately
$37&nbsp;million of this difference is related to a reduction in foreign exchange losses. This line item in 2004 primarily consisted of foreign exchange losses of approximately $39&nbsp;million,
the accretion of $58&nbsp;million for the discounted value of our liability to purchase CCEAG shares (refer to Note&nbsp;7 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements) and the minority
shareowners' proportional share of net income on certain consolidated subsidiaries. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Gains on Issuances of Stock by Equity Method Investees  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;When one of our equity method investees issues additional shares to third parties, our percentage ownership interest in the investee decreases. In the event the
issuance price per share is higher or lower than our
average carrying amount per share, we recognize a noncash gain or loss on the issuance, when appropriate. This noncash gain or loss, net of any deferred taxes, is recognized in our net income in the
period the change of ownership interest occurs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2005, our Company recorded approximately $23&nbsp;million of noncash pretax gains on the issuances of stock by equity method investees. The issuances primarily related to Coca-Cola
Amatil's issuance of common stock in connection with the acquisition of SPC Ardmona Pty.&nbsp;Ltd., an Australian packaged fruit company. These issuances of common stock reduced our ownership
interest in the total outstanding shares of Coca-Cola Amatil from approximately 34&nbsp;percent to approximately 32&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2004, our Company recorded approximately $24&nbsp;million of noncash pretax gains due to the issuances of stock by CCE. The issuances primarily related to the exercise of CCE stock
options by CCE employees at amounts greater than the book value per share of our investment in CCE. These issuances of stock reduced our ownership interest in the total outstanding shares of CCE
common stock from approximately 37&nbsp;percent to approximately 36&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2003, our Company recorded approximately $8&nbsp;million of noncash pretax gains on issuances of stock by equity method investees. These gains primarily related to the issuance by
CCE of common stock valued at an amount greater than the book value per share of our investment in CCE. These issuances of stock reduced our ownership interest in the total outstanding shares of CCE
common stock by less than 1&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Income Taxes  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our effective tax rate reflects tax benefits derived from significant operations outside the United States, which are generally taxed at rates lower than the U.S.
statutory rate of 35&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>52</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_ds1033_1_53"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
effective tax rate of approximately 27.2&nbsp;percent for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, included the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>an
income tax benefit primarily related to the Philippines impairment charges at a rate of approximately 4&nbsp;percent;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>an
income tax benefit of approximately $101&nbsp;million related to the reversal of previously accrued taxes resulting from the favorable resolution of various tax
matters; and

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
effective tax rate of approximately 22.1&nbsp;percent for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, included the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>an
income tax benefit of approximately $128&nbsp;million related to the reversal of previously accrued taxes resulting from the favorable resolution of various tax
matters;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>an
income tax benefit on "Other Operating Charges," discussed above, at a rate of approximately 36&nbsp;percent;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>an
income tax provision of approximately $75&nbsp;million related to the recording of a valuation allowance on deferred tax assets of CCEAG; and

income tax benefit of approximately $50&nbsp;million as a result of the realization of certain tax credits related to the Jobs Creation Act. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
effective tax rate of approximately 20.9&nbsp;percent for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, included the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>an
income tax benefit of approximately $50&nbsp;million related to the reversal of previously accrued taxes resulting from the favorable resolution of various tax matters
partially offset by additional taxes primarily related to the repatriation of funds;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
effective tax rate for the costs related to the streamlining initiatives of approximately 33&nbsp;percent;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
effective tax rate for the proceeds received related to the vitamin antitrust litigation matter of approximately 34&nbsp;percent (refer to Note&nbsp;17 of Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements); and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
effective tax rate for the charge related to a Latin American equity method investee of approximately 3&nbsp;percent. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based
on current tax laws, the Company's effective tax rate in 2006 is expected to be approximately 24&nbsp;percent before considering the effect of any unusual or special items that
may affect our tax rate in future years. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity, Capital Resources and Financial Position  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe our ability to generate cash from operating activities is one of our fundamental financial strengths. We expect cash flows from operating activities to
be strong in 2006 and in future years. For the five-year period from 2006 through 2010, we currently estimate that cumulative net cash provided by operating activities will be at least
$30&nbsp;billion. Accordingly, our Company expects to meet all of our financial commitments and operating needs during this time frame. We expect to use cash generated from operating activities
primarily for dividends, share repurchases, acquisitions and aggregate contractual obligations. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>53</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=55,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=586969,FOLIO='53',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DS1033A.;56',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1033_1_54"> </A>
<BR>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Cash Flows from Operating Activities  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash provided by operating activities for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 was approximately $6.4&nbsp;billion, $6.0&nbsp;billion
and $5.5&nbsp;billion, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
flows from operating activities increased by 8&nbsp;percent for 2005 compared to 2004. The increase was primarily related to an increase in cash receipts from customers, which was
driven by a 6&nbsp;percent growth in net operating revenues. These higher cash collections were offset by increased payments to suppliers and vendors, including payments related to our increased
marketing spending. Our cash flows from operating activities in 2005 also improved versus 2004 as a result of a $137&nbsp;million reduction in payments related to our 2003 streamlining initiatives.
Refer to Note&nbsp;18 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. Cash flows from operating activities in the current year were unfavorably impacted by a $176&nbsp;million increase in income
tax payments primarily related to payment of a portion of the tax provision associated with the repatriation of previously unremitted foreign earnings under the Jobs Creation Act. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
flows from operating activities increased by 9&nbsp;percent for 2004 compared to 2003. The increase was primarily related to an increase in cash receipts from customers, which was
driven by a 4&nbsp;percent growth in net operating revenues. Our cash flows from operating activities in 2004 also improved versus 2003 due to a $62&nbsp;million reduction in payments related to
our 2003 streamlining initiatives. Refer to Note&nbsp;18 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. Cash flows from operating activities in 2004 were unfavorably impacted by a
$175&nbsp;million increase in income tax payments. </FONT></P>

<UL>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Purchases of property, plant and equipment accounted for the most significant cash outlays for investing activities in each of the three years
ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. Our Company currently estimates that purchases of property, plant and equipment in 2006 will be approximately $1.3&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total
capital expenditures for property, plant and equipment (including our investments in information technology) and the percentage of such totals by operating segment for 2005, 2004
and 2003 were as follows: </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>54</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=56,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=971737,FOLIO='54',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DS1033A.;56',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1033_1_55"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Acquisitions and investments represented the next most significant investing activity, accounting for $637&nbsp;million in 2005,
$267&nbsp;million in 2004 and $359&nbsp;million in 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
April&nbsp;20, 2005, our Company and Coca-Cola HBC jointly acquired Multon for a total purchase price of approximately $501&nbsp;million, split equally between the
Company and Coca-Cola HBC. During the third quarter of 2005, our Company acquired the German soft drink bottling company Bremer for approximately $160&nbsp;million from InBev SA. Also in
2005, the Company acquired Sucos Mais, a Brazilian juice company, and completed the acquisition of the remaining 49&nbsp;percent interest in the business of CCDA Waters L.L.C. ("CCDA") not
previously owned by our Company. Refer to Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2004, proceeds from disposals of property, plant and equipment of approximately $341&nbsp;million related primarily to the sale of production assets in Japan. Refer to Note&nbsp;2
of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. In 2004, cash payments for acquisitions and investments were primarily related to the purchase of trademarks in Latin America. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2003, our single largest acquisition requiring the use of cash was the purchase of a 100&nbsp;percent ownership interest in Truesdale Packaging Company LLC ("Truesdale") from our
equity method investee CCE for approximately $58&nbsp;million. Truesdale owns a noncarbonated beverage production facility. In 2003, acquisitions of intangible assets totaled approximately
$142&nbsp;million. Of this amount, approximately $88&nbsp;million was related to the Company's acquisition of certain intangible assets with indefinite lives, primarily trademarks and brands in
various parts of the world. None of these trademarks and brands were considered individually significant. Additionally, the Company acquired certain indefinite-lived brands and related definite-lived
contractual rights, with an estimated useful life of 10&nbsp;years, from Panamco valued at $54&nbsp;million in the Latin America operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
July&nbsp;2003, we made a convertible loan of approximately $133&nbsp;million to The Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Egypt ("TCCBCE") which is included in the line item
purchases of investments and other assets in our consolidated statement of cash flows. The loan is convertible into preferred shares of TCCBCE upon receipt of governmental approvals. Additionally,
upon certain defaults under either the loan agreement or the terms of the preferred shares, we have the ability to convert the loan or the preferred shares into common shares. At December&nbsp;31,
2003, our Company owned approximately 42&nbsp;percent of the common shares of TCCBCE. The Company consolidated TCCBCE under Interpretation 46(R) effective April&nbsp;2, 2004. Refer to
Note&nbsp;1 and Note&nbsp;2 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
November&nbsp;2003, Coca-Cola HBC approved a share capital reduction totaling approximately 473&nbsp;million euros and the return of 2 euros per share to all
shareowners. In December&nbsp;2003, our Company received our share capital return payment from Coca-Cola HBC equivalent to $136&nbsp;million which is included in the line item other
investing activities in our consolidated statement of cash flows. Refer to Note&nbsp;2 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<UL>

</UL>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>55</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=57,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1001776,FOLIO='55',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DS1033A.;56',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1033_1_56"> </A>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Debt Financing  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company maintains debt levels we consider prudent based on our cash flow, interest coverage ratio and percentage of debt to capital. We use debt financing to
lower our overall cost of capital, which increases our return on shareowners' equity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2005, our long-term debt was rated "A+" by Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and "Aa3" by Moody's, and our commercial paper program was rated
"A-1" and "P-1" by
Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and Moody's, respectively. In assessing our credit strength, both Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and Moody's consider our capital structure and financial policies as well as the
aggregated balance sheet and other financial information for the Company and certain bottlers, including CCE and Coca-Cola HBC. While the Company has no legal obligation for the debt of
these bottlers, the rating agencies believe the strategic importance of the bottlers to the Company's business model provides the Company with an incentive to keep these bottlers viable. If our credit
ratings were reduced by the rating agencies, our interest expense could increase. Additionally, if certain bottlers' credit ratings were to decline, the Company's share of equity income could be
reduced as a result of the potential increase in interest expense for these bottlers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
monitor our interest coverage ratio and, as indicated above, the rating agencies consider our ratio in assessing our credit ratings. However, the rating agencies aggregate financial
data for certain bottlers along with our Company when assessing our debt rating. As such, the key measure to rating agencies is the aggregate interest coverage ratio of the Company and certain
bottlers. Both Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and Moody's employ different aggregation methodologies and have different thresholds for the aggregate interest coverage ratio. These thresholds are not
necessarily permanent, nor are they fully disclosed to our Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
global presence and strong capital position give us access to key financial markets around the world, enabling us to raise funds at a low effective cost. This posture, coupled with
active management of our mix of short-term and long-term debt and our mix of fixed-rate and variable-rate debt, results in a lower overall cost of borrowing. Our debt
management policies, in conjunction with our share repurchase programs and investment activity, can result in current liabilities exceeding current assets. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Issuances
and payments of debt included both short-term and long-term financing activities. On December&nbsp;31, 2005, we had $1,794&nbsp;million in lines of
credit and other short-term credit facilities available, of which approximately $266&nbsp;million was outstanding. This entire $266&nbsp;million related to our international
operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
issuances of debt in 2005 primarily included approximately $144&nbsp;million of issuances of commercial paper with maturities of 90&nbsp;days or more. The payments of debt
primarily included approximately $1,037&nbsp;million related to net repayments of commercial paper with maturities of less than 90&nbsp;days, repayments of commercial paper with maturities greater
than 90&nbsp;days of approximately $32&nbsp;million and repayment of approximately $1,363&nbsp;million of long-term debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
issuances of debt in 2004 primarily included approximately $2,109&nbsp;million of net issuances of commercial paper with maturities of 90&nbsp;days or less, and approximately
$818&nbsp;million of issuances of commercial paper with maturities of more than 90&nbsp;days. The payments of debt in 2004 primarily included approximately $927&nbsp;million related to
commercial paper with maturities of more than 90&nbsp;days and $367&nbsp;million of long-term debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
issuances of debt in 2003 primarily included approximately $304&nbsp;million of net issuances of commercial paper with maturities of 90&nbsp;days or less, and approximately
$715&nbsp;million of issuances of commercial paper with maturities of more than 90&nbsp;days. The payments of debt in 2003 primarily included approximately $907&nbsp;million related to
commercial paper with maturities of more than 90&nbsp;days and $150&nbsp;million of long-term debt. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>56</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<UL>

</UL>

The table below presents shares repurchased and average price per share under the 1996 Plan: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since the inception of our initial share repurchase program in 1984 through our current program as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, we have purchased
more than 1.1&nbsp;billion shares of our Company's common stock at an average price per share of $16.24. This represents approximately 36&nbsp;percent of the shares outstanding as of
January&nbsp;1, 1984. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, 2004 and 2003, the Company repurchased common stock under the 1996 Plan. As strong cash flows are expected to continue in the future, the Company currently expects 2006
share repurchases to be in the range of $2.0&nbsp;billion to $2.5&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Dividends  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At its February&nbsp;2006 meeting, our Board of Directors increased our quarterly dividend by 11 percent, raising it to $0.31 per share, equivalent to a
full-year dividend of $1.24 per share in 2006. This is our 44<SUP>th</SUP> consecutive annual increase. Our annual common stock dividend was $1.12 per share, $1.00 per share and $0.88
per share in 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively. The 2005 dividend represented a 12&nbsp;percent increase from 2004, and the 2004 dividend represented a 14&nbsp;percent increase from 2003. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements and Aggregate Contractual Obligations  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with the definition under SEC rules, the following qualify as off-balance sheet arrangements: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>any
obligation under certain guarantee contracts;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>a
retained or contingent interest in assets transferred to an unconsolidated entity or similar arrangement that serves as credit, liquidity or market risk support to that
entity for such assets;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>any
obligation under certain derivative instruments; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>any
obligation arising out of a material variable interest held by the registrant in an unconsolidated entity that provides financing, liquidity, market risk or credit risk
support to the registrant, or engages in leasing, hedging or research and development services with the registrant. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following discusses certain obligations and arrangements involving our Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;31, 2005, our Company was contingently liable for guarantees of indebtedness owed by third parties in the amount of approximately $248&nbsp;million. Management
concluded that the likelihood of any material amounts being paid by our Company is not probable. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, we were not directly liable for the debt of any unconsolidated entity,
and we did not have any retained or contingent interest in assets as defined above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company recognizes all derivative instruments as either assets or liabilities at fair value in our consolidated balance sheets. Refer to Note&nbsp;11 and Note&nbsp;12 of Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2003, we granted a $250&nbsp;million standby line of credit to Coca-Cola FEMSA with normal market terms. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, no amounts have
been drawn against this line of credit. This standby line of credit expires in December&nbsp;2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;87, "Employers' Accounting for Pensions," and SFAS No.&nbsp;106, "Employers' Accounting for Postretirement
Benefits Other Than Pensions," the total accrued benefit liability for pension and other postretirement benefit plans recognized as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, was $1,221&nbsp;million. Refer to
Note&nbsp;15 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. This accrued liability is included in the consolidated balance sheet line item other liabilities. This amount is impacted by, among other
items, funding levels, changes in plan </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>58</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=14,SEQ=60,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=317817,FOLIO='58',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DS1033A.;56',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1033_1_59"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>demographics
and assumptions, and investment return on plan assets. Because the accrued liability does not represent expected liquidity needs, we did not include this amount in the contractual
obligations table. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
fund our U.S. qualified pension plans in accordance with Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 regulations for the minimum annual required contribution and in accordance
with Internal Revenue Service regulations for the maximum annual allowable tax deduction. The minimum required contribution for our primary qualified U.S. pension plan for the 2006 plan year is $0 and
is anticipated to remain $0 for at least the next several years due to contributions made to the plan between 2001 and 2005. Therefore, we did not include any amounts as a contractual obligation in
the above table. We do, however, anticipate contributing up to the maximum deductible amount to the primary U.S. qualified pension plan in 2006, which is estimated to be approximately
$60&nbsp;million. Furthermore, we expect to contribute up to $9&nbsp;million to the U.S. postretirement health care benefit plan during 2006. We generally expect to fund all future contributions
with cash flows from operating activities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
international pension plans are funded in accordance with local laws and income tax regulations. We do not expect contributions to these plans to be material in 2006 or thereafter.
Therefore, no amounts have been included in the table above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the projected benefit obligation of the U.S. qualified pension plans was $1,626&nbsp;million, and the fair value of plan assets was
$1,881&nbsp;million. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the projected benefit obligation of all pension plans other than the U.S. qualified pension plans was $1,415&nbsp;million, and the fair value
of all other pension plan assets was $756&nbsp;million. The majority of this underfunding is attributable to an international pension plan for certain non-U.S. employees that is unfunded
due to tax law restrictions, as well as our unfunded U.S. nonqualified pension plans. These U.S. nonqualified pension plans provide, for certain associates, benefits that are not permitted to be
funded through a qualified plan because of limits imposed by the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Disclosure of amounts in the above table regarding expected benefit payments for our unfunded pension
plans and our other postretirement benefit plans cannot be properly reflected for 2011 and thereafter due to the ongoing nature of the obligations of these plans. However, in order to inform the
reader about expected benefit payments for these unfunded plans over the next several years, we anticipate annual benefit payments to be in the range of approximately $50&nbsp;million to
$60&nbsp;million in 2006 and remain at or near this annual level for the next several years. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred
income tax liabilities as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, were $511&nbsp;million. Refer to Note&nbsp;16 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. This amount is not
included in the total contractual obligations table
because we believe this presentation would not be meaningful. Deferred income tax liabilities are calculated based on temporary differences between the tax basis of assets and liabilities and their
book basis, which will result in taxable amounts in future years when the book basis is settled. The results of these calculations do not have a direct connection with the amount of cash taxes to be
paid in any future periods. As a result, scheduling deferred income tax liabilities as payments due by period could be misleading, because this scheduling would not relate to liquidity needs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Minority
interests of $151 million as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, for consolidated entities in which we do not have a 100&nbsp;percent ownership interest were recorded in the
consolidated balance sheet line item other liabilities. Such minority interests are not liabilities requiring the use of cash or other resources; therefore, this amount is excluded from the
contractual obligations table. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Foreign Exchange  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our international operations are subject to opportunities and risks relating to foreign currency fluctuations. We closely monitor our operations in each country
and seek to adopt appropriate strategies that are responsive to fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>59</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;These percentages do not include the effects of our hedging activities and, therefore, do not reflect the actual impact of fluctuations in
exchange rates on our operating results. Our foreign currency management program is designed to mitigate, over time, a portion of the impact of exchange rates on net income and earnings per share. The
total currency impact on operating income, including the effect of our hedging activities, was an increase of approximately 4&nbsp;percent, 8&nbsp;percent and 2&nbsp;percent in 2005, 2004 and
2003, respectively. In 2006, the Company expects a negative impact on operating income from currencies. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exchange
losses&#151;net amounted to approximately $23&nbsp;million in 2005, $39&nbsp;million in 2004 and $76&nbsp;million in 2003 and were recorded in other
loss&#151;net in our consolidated statements of income. Exchange losses&#151;net include the remeasurement of monetary assets and liabilities from certain currencies into functional
currencies and the costs of hedging certain exposures of our consolidated balance sheets. Refer to Note&nbsp;11 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company will continue to manage its foreign currency exposure to mitigate, over time, a portion of the impact of exchange rate changes on net income and earnings per share. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Overview of Financial Position  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our consolidated balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, compared to our consolidated balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2004, was impacted by the
following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
decrease in loans and notes payable of $13&nbsp;million was primarily due to the decrease of commercial paper borrowings during 2005 of $924&nbsp;million and was
offset by the reclassification of the payment to be made to CCEAG shareholders from other liabilities to loans and notes payable. Refer to Note&nbsp;7 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
increase in our equity method investments in 2005 of $665&nbsp;million was primarily due to the payment of approximately $250&nbsp;million for our share of the joint
acquisition of Multon. The increase also includes the impact of the strength in most key currencies versus the U.S. dollar and equity income, net of dividends. Refer to Note&nbsp;2 of Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
overall decrease in total assets of $2,014&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, compared to December&nbsp;31, 2004, was primarily related to the decrease in
cash and cash equivalents, which impacted the Corporate operating segment. The decrease was also due to impairment charges primarily for trademarks amounting to approximately $85&nbsp;million. The
decrease was partially offset by the impact of the strength in most key currencies versus the U.S. dollar, especially a stronger Brazilian real and Mexican peso (which impacted the Latin America
operating segment) and a stronger euro (which </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<!-- ZEQ.=16,SEQ=62,EFW="2167326",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=888587,FOLIO='60',FILE='DISK130:[06ATA3.06ATA1033]DS1033A.;56',USER='SCAVALI',CD='28-FEB-2006;11:17' -->
